summary: 11/28/2011: Members of Al-Shabaab stormed an international aid office in Beledweyne, Hiran province, Somalia. Gunmen forced staff members to leave and occupied the space, shutting the office down. There were no reported casualties or injuries; however, witnesses reported seeing the attackers removing office equipment and vaccines from the agency. This incident was part of a coordinated attack; Al-Shabaab members stormed other international aid offices in the country at the same time. The attacks followed the announcement that the militant group was banning 16 aid agencies, including UNICEF; the ban was in response to the "illegal acts" perpetrated by the agencies, such as exaggerating the caliber of the problems within Somalia for financial and political gain.

summary: 07/14/2009: On Tuesday morning, in Mogadishu, Banaadir, Somalia, two French intelligence agents, Marc Aubriere and Denis Allex, were kidnapped. Approximately 12 armed assailants, some in uniform, went from room to room at the Sahafi Hotel looking for the two men, who were driven away in a car and a pickup truck mounted with machine guns. The ransom amount for one of the captives, a lieutenant colonel, was 8,000,000 (USD). On 08/25/2009, Aubriere escaped. Conflicting reports regarding Allex indicate that he was killed in January 2013, either during an unsuccessful raid by French troops on January 12, 2013, or by his captors on January 16, 2013. Al-Shabaab al-Islamiya, the Islamic Party, and an unknown sub-clan separately claimed responsibility. Al Shabaab issued the claim that they had executed Allex via Twitter.

motive: The attack occurred hours after Al-Shabaab al-Islamiya issued a statement about these offices saying that they were working against the benefit of the Somali Muslim population and against the establishment of an Islamic state in Somalia
summary: 07/20/2009: On Monday, in one of three related attacks, assailants raided the offices of the United Nations (UN) Development Program, UN Department of Safety and Security and the UN Political Office for Somalia in the southern towns of Baidoa, Bay, Somalia and Wadajir, Bakol, Somalia. The assailants prevented a number of UN employees from leaving while they stole vehicles and equipment. Al-Shabaab al-Islamiya claimed responsibility. The attack occurred hours after Al-Shabaab al-Islamiya issued a statement about these offices saying that they were working against the benefit of the Somali Muslim population and against the establishment of an Islamic state in Somalia. According to the Nairobi-based UN office for Somalia, staff was relocated and United Nations operations were temporarily suspended in Baidoa as a result of the raids; however, operations continued in Wajid.

At least two soldiers were killed and at least three were injured in the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
11/10/2020: Assailants opened fire on a mosque in Guriceel, Galguduud, Somalia. No casualties were reported in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

11/11/2020: An explosive device detonated in the residence of Aidi Saleman Hashi, the Jubaland Environment and Tourism Minister, in Kismayo, Lower Juba, Somalia. Hashi was not harmed, but three bodyguards were killed in the blast. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident.
target: home of environmental and tourism minister: aidi saleman hashi

summary: 11/17/2020: A suicide bomber detonated in a restaurant near General Kahiye Police Academy in Mogadishu, Banaadir, Somalia. In addition to the assailant, at least five people were killed and eight were injured in the blast. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident.
weapon_detail_new: an explosives-laden vest was used in the attack.

summary: 11/18/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting an African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) convoy in Kaaraan neighborhood, Mogadishu, Banaadir, Somalia. No casualties were reported in the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

11/19/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting military personnel in Lafoole, Lower Shebelle, Somalia. At least one soldier was killed and three others, including civilians and soldiers, were injured in the blast. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident.

11/20/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting Puntland security forces in Galkayo, Mudug, Somalia. At least one soldier was killed and two others were injured in the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

11/23/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting a Danab Militia convoy in Leego, Lower Shebelle, Somalia. At least six Danab Militia members were killed and several others were injured in the blast. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident.

12/31/2013: Assailants attacked a wedding party in Suuqa Xoolaha area, Mogadishu city, Banaadir region, Somalia. No one was injured; however, music equipment was destroyed in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources suspect the involvement of al-Shabaab.
weapon_detail_new: pistols were used in the attack.

summary: 11/25/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting a police vehicle near Ceelasha Biyaha, Lower Shebelle, Somalia. At least five police officers were killed and several others were injured in the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.

11/27/2020: A suicide bomber detonated at Gelato Divino restaurant near the KM-4 junction in Mogadishu, Banaadir, Somalia. At least seven people, including an employee of the Somali Embassy in Ethiopia, were killed and 10 were injured in the blast. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident.
11/27/2020: Security forces arrested an assailant attempting to plant an explosive device in Dhusamareb, Galguduud, Somalia. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

11/28/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting Ahmed Washington, a port official in Miranayo area, Abdi Aziz district, Mogadishu, Banaadir, Somalia. Washington was unharmed, but two of his aides were killed in the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

11/30/2020: Assailants attacked a Somali National Army (SNA) base in Bacaadweyn village, Mudug, Somalia. At least 66 people, including four soldiers, 11 civilians, and 51 assailants, were killed and at least six assailants were wounded in the ensuing clash. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.

04/01/2018: Assailants shot and killed a women's rights activist in Huriwa neighborhood, Mogadishu, Somalia. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.

12/09/2020: Assailants opened fire on a Somali military convoy in Balanbale area, near Guriceel, Galguduud, Somalia. Six soldiers were killed, and three were injured in the ambush. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

02/03/2014: Assailants fired mortars at Hamar-Jajab district, Mogadishu city, Banaadir region, Somalia. It is unknown if the attack resulted in casualties. This was one of four mortar attacks on the city by the same group. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident.
weapon_detail_new: mortars were used in the attack.

summary: 02/03/2014: Assailants fired mortars in Hamar-Weyne district, Mogadishu city, Banaadir region, Somalia. No casualties or damages were reported in the attack. This was one of four mortar attacks on the city by the same group. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident.
weapon_detail_new: mortars were used in the attack.

summary: 12/10/2020: Assailants ambushed South-West State Army soldiers at a checkpoint in Wanlaweyne, Lower Shebelle, Somalia. Four soldiers were killed, and two were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

12/11/2020: Assailants abducted three gold miners in Milho, Sanaag, Somalia. The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.

12/12/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting a Somali military convoy along Abdiqaasim Road, near K-4 junction, Mogadishu, Banaadir, Somalia. There were no reported casualties in the attack. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources suspected the involvement of Al-Shabaab.

12/13/2020: An explosive device detonated outside the Galkayo district headquarters in Galkayo, Mudug, Somalia. At least four people were injured in the blast, including two soldiers and Abdirahman Sheikh Hassan, the district commissioner. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

12/13/2020: Assailants attacked Somali National Army (SNA) personnel in Wajid, Bakool, Somalia. The attack was repelled and at least eight assailants were killed in the ensuing clash. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.

12/14/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting a Burundian African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) vehicle in Huriwa, Mogadishu, Banaadir, Somalia. No casualties were reported in the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

12/18/2020: A suicide bomber detonated targeting a rally for Prime Minister Mohamed Hussein Roble at Abdullahi Isse Stadium in Galkayo, Mudug, Somalia. In addition to the assailant, at least 21 people were killed, including three senior military officials and a former mayor, and at least 19 people were injured in the blast. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident.
weapon_detail_new: an explosives-laden vest was used in the attack.
target: rally of prime minister: mohamed hussein roble

summary: 12/19/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting the Ma'awisley Militia in Hawl Wadag neighborhood, Beledweyne, Hiiraan, Somalia. One militia member was killed. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

11/23/2014: Assailants set fire to buildings in Xamiir Gaabo village, Hiiraan region, Somalia. There were no reported casualties in the attack. This was one of two arson incidents targeting villages in Hiiraan on the same day. No group claimed responsibility; however sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.

motive: The specific motive for the attack is unknown.
summary: 05/08/2010: On Saturday, in Ceel Barde near Xuddur, Bakool, Somalia, unknown assailants attacked the town by unknown means and took control of it; no casualties or damages were reported. No group claimed responsibility, but the militant group al-Shabaab is thought to be responsible for the attack.
weapon_detail_new: unknown weapons were used in the attack.

summary: 12/28/2020: Assailants attacked an African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) base near Ceel Waaq, Gedo, Somalia. At least one Kenyan soldier was killed in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.

motive: Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the intelligence officers were targeted because they harassed locals
summary: 12/28/2020: Assailants opened fire on National Intelligence and Security Agency (NISA) members in Bundoyinka, Mogadishu, Banaadir, Somalia. At least four NISA members were killed in the attack. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the victims were members of a security force unit that harassed locals.
weapon_detail_new: pistols were used in the attack.

summary: 12/29/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting the vehicle of Muhidin Hassan Afrah, a former member of parliament, in Kaaraan, Mogadishu, Banaadir, Somalia. Afrah was not harmed, but his bodyguard was killed, and two others were injured in the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.

summary: 09/29/2018: Assailants held an unknown number of civilians hostage and attempted to extort money from them in Yaqle, Middle Shebelle, Somalia. The hostages were released shortly thereafter and no casualties were reported. This was one of three related attacks in the area on this date. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incidents.
